Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a High Resolution LC/MS/MS to Enable Undergraduate Chemical and Biochemical Research Across Six Disciplines in the Natural and Applied Sciences at Hope College
Award.AbstractNarration: This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation programs. Hope College is acquiring a liquid chromatograph, quadrupole, time-of-flight, tandem mass spectrometer (LC-Q-TOF-MS/MS)to support Professor Kristin Dittenhafer-Reed and colleagues Jonathan Peterson, Kenneth Brown, Jason Gillmore and Matthew Smith. In general, mass spectrometry (MS) is one of the key analytical methods used to identify and characterize small quantities of chemical species in complex matrices. In a typical experiment, the components flow into a mass spectrometer where they are ionized into the parent ion and its fragment ions and their masses are measured. This highly sensitive technique allows detection and determination of the structure of molecules in a complex mixture. A MS instrument with a liquid chromatograph provides additional structural identification power by separating mixtures of compounds before they reach the mass spectrometer. In the time-of-flight (TOF) method of mass spectrometry, the mass-to-charge ratio of an ion is determined by the way in which ions are accelerated by an electric field of known strength. The velocity of the ion depends on the mass-to-charge ratio (heavier ions of the same charge have lower speeds). The time that the ions take to reach a detector at a known distance is measured. This time depends on the velocity of the ion, and therefore is a measure of its mass-to-charge ratio. From this ratio and known experimental parameters, the ion can be characterized. The acquisition strengthens the research infrastructure at the College and regional area. The instrument broadens participation by involving diverse students in research and research training using this modern analytical technique. The acquisition provides training opportunities to a large number of undergraduate students through a variety of activities such as those studying local watersheds.<br/><br/>The award of the mass spectrometer is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels. The instrument acquisition especially impacts studies of proteins, protein post-translational modification, and metabolites. The instrumentation is used for quantifying and analyzing lipids. In addition, the LC-Q-TOF-MS/MS is helpful in studying chemical structures, syntheses, and mechanisms of photo- and electroactive heteroaromatic compounds. The mass spectrometer is also used to carry out studies related to the environment such as those related to water quality and surface interactions of nanoparticles which are helpful to understand the fate and transport of pharmaceuticals.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Hope College received funds through the National Science Foundation Major Research Instrumentation program to acquire a tandem high-resolution mass spectrometer to enable molecular analyses in three main areas of chemistry. These three areas include: 1) chemistry of life processes and analysis of proteins and metabolites; 2) analysis of chemical structures, synthesis, and mechanisms; and 3) environmental chemistry projects characterizing small molecules in soil, water, and peat samples. An Agilent 6545 Q-TOF LC/MS (quadrupole time of flight liquid chromatography/mass spectrometer) system was installed at Hope College. The instrument enabled and accelerated impactful research from departments across the Natural and Applied Sciences Division at Hope College, including Chemistry, Biochemistry, Biology, Engineering, Geology & Environmental Science, and Neuroscience.

Intellectual Merit: The LC/Q-TOF system enabled eight research groups at Hope College to perform critical molecular analyses spanning the chemical sciences. The instrument provided essential data for peer-reviewed publications and scientific poster presentations at national, regional, and local meetings. The data obtained with the instrument also enhanced competitiveness for other research funding, advancing research progress.

In the area of life science, instrument users focused on the study of molecular details that control cell processes. One group used the instrument to study the mitochondria, the energy production centers of cells. Other groups focused their effort on the study of the role of oxidative stress in neurodegenerative conditions using cell and animal models. Additionally, the instrument enabled the characterization of small molecules derived from seed extracts that may have antifungal properties. Other chemists used the instrument to support the development of small molecule synthesis techniques and the characterization of new synthetic dyes. In the environmental science area, the instrument was used to investigate the interactions between antibiotic drugs and oxide nanoparticles in order to understand the fate and transport of pharmaceuticals and personal care products in the environment. The outcomes of this work may be used to inform proper disposal and usage decisions for pharmaceuticals and personal care products that will positively impact environmental conditions. In a separate project, the instrument was used to evaluate how peat bogs respond to past climate change.

Broader Impacts: This funding supported training opportunities for undergraduate research students on this cutting-edge technology at Hope College, an undergraduate-only institution. Eight undergraduate research groups, including faculty and undergraduate students, used the instrument independently to acquire data for their respective projects. The instrument will be highlighted in an upcoming course for upper-level chemistry majors, expanding the exposure to the technology and hands-on use of the instrument. Through training and use of the mass spectrometer, our students are obtaining valuable skillsets for their future careers in science. Use of the results in the classroom can also enhance student learning in chemistry and biochemistry. We envision the number of undergraduate students impacted by the use the instrument will continue to grow in the future, both through individual research projects and teaching labs.

The work enabled through the use of the instrumentation also has scientific broader impacts. The biochemical projects focus on basic science questions that have the potential to impact human health. The synthetic work has relevance to advancing material science and pharmaceuticals. Perhaps most significantly, the geology and environmental science projects supported have environmental impacts and may inform environmental policy.

Summary: The installation of the Q-TOF LC/MS has accelerated research progress, opened new doors for scientific study, and allowed for the dissemination of results in posters, talks, and peer-reviewed publications with diverse scientific broader impacts. The project also led to the training of the next generation of leaders in the scientific community, and will continue to do so for many years to come.
